results.headline: Review: ‘Farewell to Hollywood,’ the Last Years of a Budding Filmmaker
results.summary_short: This documentary, co-directed by Regina Nicholson, who died of cancer at 19 in 2012, is moving yet queasily unsettling.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Farewell to Hollywood

results.headline: Review: ‘Wild Tales’ Explores the Blurred Limits of Morality
results.summary_short: This Argentine anthology, an Oscar nominee for best foreign-language film, looks at human behavior when pushed to the extremes.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Relatos salvajes

results.headline: Review: In ‘McFarland, USA,’ Kevin Costner Coaches Cross-Country Runners
results.summary_short: In “McFarland USA,” Mr. Costner leads a team of Hispanic high schoolers to a championship, while getting closer to them and their families.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of McFarland, USA

results.headline: Review: In ‘Approaching the Elephant,’ an Experimental Classroom Jungle
results.summary_short: By simply observing and making no judgments, a documentary explores how children behave when classroom routines — or a lack thereof — are totally up to them.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Approaching the Elephant

results.headline: Review: ‘Hot Tub Time Machine 2’ Heads Back to the Bubbles
results.summary_short: The sequel to “Hot Tub Time Machine” features Rob Corddry and Craig Robinson playing characters who have benefited from learning about the future in the first film.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hot Tub Time Machine 2

results.headline: Review: In ‘The DUFF,’ a Wounded Teenage Girl Combats Mockery
results.summary_short: When a student learns she is called the “designated ugly fat friend,” she sets out on a makeover without realizing that vindictiveness is the real problem.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The DUFF

results.headline: Review: With ‘Queen and Country,’ John Boorman Continues a Tale
results.summary_short: Mr. Boorman’s new film picks up where “Hope and Glory” left off, with a young Briton as he comes into adulthood during the Korean War.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Queen and Country

results.display_title: What We Do in the Shadows
results.headline: Review: ‘What We Do in the Shadows,’ a Vampire Comedy
results.summary_short: The film, directed by Jemaine Clement and Taika Waititi, is set in New Zealand and follows four ghouls who have problems adapting to the modern world.

results.display_title: Gett le procès de Viviane Amsalem
results.headline: Review: In ‘Gett: The Trial of Viviane Amsalem,’ a Woman Fights for Her Freedom
results.summary_short: Ronit Elkabetz plays a woman who is determined to escape her marriage, although the rabbinic power structure is stacked against her.

results.headline: Review: ‘Wyrmwood: Road of the Dead’ Puts Zombies in the Outback
results.summary_short: A mechanic is pitted against the undead in this go-for-broke style film set in an apocalyptic Australian outback.

results.headline: Review: ‘The Last Five Years,’ a Decoupling Starring Anna Kendrick
results.summary_short: In “The Last Five Years,” adapted from the play of the same name, a novelist and an actress grow apart.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last Five Years

results.headline: Review: In ‘White Rabbit,’ a Bullied Teenager Is Pushed to the Edge
results.summary_short: The director Tim McCann’s drama about a disturbed loner stars Nick Krause, Britt Robertson and Sam Trammell.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of White Rabbit

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Rewrite,’ Hugh Grant Is an Author Seeking a Comeback
results.summary_short: Marc Lawrence’s comedy focuses on a formerly successful screenwriter who takes a teaching job at Binghamton University.

results.headline: Review: In ‘Kingsman: The Secret Service,’ Colin Firth Get His Suits Splattered
results.summary_short: There’s a fine cast — including Michael Caine, Mark Strong and Samuel L. Jackson — as well as exploding heads and endangered dogs in Matthew Vaughn’s gory action movie.

results.headline: Review: ‘Hits,’ a Comedy, Lampoons Internet Fame
results.summary_short: An upstate New York man’s rant against perceived injustices goes viral in this David Cross film.

results.headline: Review: ‘Da Sweet Blood of Jesus,’ Spike Lee’s Vampire Movie
results.summary_short: This remake of Bill Gunn’s “Ganja and Hess” is a stylishly shot, coolly contemplative homage to the original.

results.headline: Review: ‘Costa da Morte’ Lustrously Depicts Extreme Coastlines
results.summary_short: The filmmaker Lois Patiño’s subject, the Coast of Death in Galicia, Spain, earned its name from a history of shipwrecks.

results.headline: Review: In ‘Fifty Shades of Grey’ Movie, Sex Is a Knotty Business
results.summary_short: The film dabbles in romantic comedy and splashes around in melodrama, but the one thing it can’t be is what E. L. James’s novel was, trashily and triumphantly: pornography.

results.headline: Cleaning Lady Has No Idea of Her Crucial Role in the Cosmos
results.summary_short: In “Jupiter Ascending,” Mila Kunis plays an earthling who turns out to be the reconstituted queen of the universe.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jupiter Ascending

results.display_title: Matt Shepard is a Friend of Mine
results.headline: Shifting the Spotlight Back to the Man They Knew
results.summary_short: “Matt Shepard Is a Friend of Mine” seeks to return a human symbol of hate crimes against gay people to a state of ordinary but beloved individuality.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Matt Shepard is a Friend of Mine
